messageBody:
Hi Thomas,

Thanks for the nice feedback.

WRT to the "new" keyword, it all depends what you are talking about. I
seem to remember that the places where I use "new" are referring either
to:
- unit testing vs functional testing (older)
- mock objects vs stubs (older)

TDD is certainly new but I don't think it in opposition to "unit
testing". It is a way of writing unit tests (it's actually more - it's a
way of developing application) and I wouldn't put "unit testing" on the
same level as "TDD".

Point taken though! Do you think you could send me a private email and
point to me where you have seen this usage of "new"?

Thanks
-Vincent

> -----Original Message-----
> From: Thomas Stankus Jr. [mailto:tjstankus@...]
> Sent: 09 July 2003 15:52
> To: junit@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: [junit] Re: JUnit in Action book
>
> Thanks for the info. I actually purchased the ebook through Manning's
MEAP
> program
> last night and read the first chapter. Well done so far! I especially
like
> the logical way
> you demonstrate the value of JUnit over old-style (non-framework) unit
> testing
> methods. This is great, convincing stuff for someone new to JUnit and
good
> ammo for
> anyone trying to convince management to invest more heavily in
up-front
> testing. I'm
> looking forward to reading subsequent chapters as they are published.
>
> I do have one sematic, nitpicky gripe. In several places, unit testing
is
> referred to as a
> "new" testing strategy. Wouldn't it be better to refer to Test Driven
> Development as
> the "new" strategy? Unit testing has been around for quite some time,
but
> TDD is
> (arguably) a new strategy.
>
> -TJ
>
